Class OSUtils

extends Object
    Utility methods relating to the Operating System.
    Author:
    Guillaume Jacob (guillaume.jacob@orcsoftware.com)

      • onWindows

        public static boolean onWindows()

        true iff. the current OS is Windows

      • onMacOSX

        public static boolean onMacOSX()
        Returns:
        true iff. the current OS is Mac OS X.

      • onASun16PlusJVM

        public static boolean onASun16PlusJVM()
        Returns:
        true if the current JVM is a Sun 1.6+ JVM, i.e. if one of the following is true:
        • The value of system property java.vm.vendor is Sun Microsystems Inc. and the value of system property java.specification.version is 1.6
        • The value of system property java.vm.vendor is "Oracle Corporation" and the value of system property java.specification.version is either1.7 or 1.8

      • onA18PlusJVM

        public static boolean onA18PlusJVM()
        Returns:
        true if the value of system property java.specification.version is one of: { 1.8 }, false otherwise

      • onA9PlusJVM

        public static boolean onA9PlusJVM()
        Returns:
        true if the value of system property java.specification.version is greater than 1.8, false otherwise

      • onA18OrLessJVM

        public static boolean onA18OrLessJVM()
        Returns:
        true if the value of system property java.specification.version is 1.8 or less, false otherwise

      • getProcessStandardOutput

        public static String getProcessStandardOutput(Process process,
                                              int limit)
                                       throws IOException
        Reads from the output stream of a process.
        Parameters:
        process - the process whose output should be read
        limit - the limit in bytes to the amount of data that should be read. Zero or negative values are interpreted as no limit
        Returns:
        up to the given limit of what the process wrote to its output stream
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when reading from the output stream of the process
        NullPointerException - if process is null

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • getPIDOnSun16PlusJVM

        public static String getPIDOnSun16PlusJVM()
        Returns the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system.

        This method is only available on Sun 1.6+ JVMs.

        Obtains the PID by inspecting the object name of the Runtime MXBean exposed by the JVM.
        Returns:
        the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on a JVM that is not a Sun 1.6 JVM

      • getPIDOnUnix

        public static String getPIDOnUnix(String[] commandSpecification)
                           throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                  UnexpectedProcessExitValueException,
                                  IOException
        Returns the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system.

        This method is only available on Unix platforms.

        Obtains the PID by launching the provided external command and reading the output.

        The given command is expected to succeed (i.e. terminate with an exit value of 0), and to generate output as follows:
        • The command's standard output should have exactlty one line.
        • The command's error output should be empty.
        If a null command is passed, the following command is used by default: sh -c ps -o ppid= -p $$
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        Returns:
        the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's output is not as expected
        UnexpectedProcessExitValueException - if the command's exit value is not 0
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows

      • getPIDOnWindows

        public static String getPIDOnWindows(String[] commandSpecification)
                              throws IOException,
                                     UnexpectedProcessExitValueException,
                                     UnexpectedProcessOutputException
        Returns the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system.

        This method is only available on Windows platforms.

        Obtains the PID by launching the provided external command and reading the output.

        The given command is expected to succeed (i.e. terminate with an exit value of 0), and to generate output as follows:
        • The command's standard output should have exactlty one line.
        • The command's error output should be empty.
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run
        Returns:
        the current JVM's PID as seen by the operating system
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's output is not as expected
        UnexpectedProcessExitValueException - if the command's exit value is not 0
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows
        NullPointerException - if commandSpecification is null

      • isProcessRunningOnUnix

        public static boolean isProcessRunningOnUnix(String[] commandSpecification,
                                             String pid)
                                      throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                             IOException
        Tells whether the process with the given PID is seen as running by the operating system.

        This method is only available on Unix platforms.

        Searches for the process with the given PID by launching an external command and checking its exit value.

        The external command that is launched is obtained by relacing every occurrence of %p in the given command by the given PID.

        The command's exit value is then interpreted as follows:
        • An exit value equal to 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is running.
        • An exit value different from 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is not running.
        The command is not expected to generate any error output.

        If a null command is passed, the following is used by default: sh -c [ -d /prod/%p ]
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        pid - the PID to look for
        Returns:
        true iff. the process with the given PID is seen as running by the operating system
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's error output is not empty
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalArgumentException - if commandSpecification does not contain at least one occurrence of the %p placeholder
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows
        NullPointerException - if pid is null

      • isProcessRunningOnMacOSX

        public static boolean isProcessRunningOnMacOSX(String[] commandSpecification,
                                               String pid)
                                        throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                               IOException
        Tells whether the process with the given PID is seen as running by the Mac OSX.

        This method is only available on Mac OSX platforms.

        Searches for the process with the given PID by launching an external command and checking its exit value.

        The external command that is launched is obtained by relacing every occurrence of %p in the given command by the given PID.

        The command's exit value is then interpreted as follows:
        • An exit value equal to 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is running.
        • An exit value different from 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is not running.
        The command is not expected to generate any error output.

        If a null command is passed, the following is used by default: sh -c [ -d /prod/%p ]
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        pid - the PID to look for
        Returns:
        true iff. the process with the given PID is seen as running by the operating system
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's error output is not empty
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalArgumentException - if commandSpecification does not contain at least one occurrence of the %p placeholder
        IllegalStateException - if not invoked on Mac OSX
        NullPointerException - if pid is null

      • isProcessRunningOnWindows

        public static boolean isProcessRunningOnWindows(String[] commandSpecification,
                                                String pid)
                                         throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                                IOException
        Tells whether the process with the given PID is seen as running by the operating system.

        This method is only available on Windows platforms.

        Searches for the process with the given PID by launching an external command and checking its exit value.

        The external command that is launched is obtained by relacing every occurrence of %p in the given command by the given PID.

        The command's exit value is then interpreted as follows:
        • An exit value equal to 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is running.
        • An exit value different from 0 (zero) indicates that the process with the given PID is not running.
        The command is not expected to generate any error output.

        If a null command is passed, the following is used by default: cmd /c tasklist /NF /FI "PID eq %p"2>NUL|find "%p">NUL
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        pid - the PID to look for
        Returns:
        true iff. the process with the given PID is seen as running by the operating system
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's error output is not empty
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalArgumentException - if commandSpecification does not contain at least one occurrence of the %p placeholder
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows
        NullPointerException - if pid is null

      • toUnixCommandSpecification

        public static String[] toUnixCommandSpecification(String command)
        Splits the given Unix command into an array of strings suitable for use with a ProcessBuilder.

        If the given command is of the form sh -c <sub-command>, the returned value will be { "sh", "-c", "<sub-command>" }. Otherwise the returned value will be { "sh", "-c", "<command>" }
        Parameters:
        command - a Unix command
        Returns:
        the corresponding command specification
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if command is null

      • toWindowsCommandSpecification

        public static String[] toWindowsCommandSpecification(String command)
        Splits the given Windows command into an array of strings suitable for use with a ProcessBuilder.

        If the given command is of the form cmd /c <sub-command>, the returned value will be { "cmd", "/c", "<sub-command>" }. Otherwise the returned value will be { "cmd", "/c", "<command>" }
        Parameters:
        command - a Windows command
        Returns:
        the corresponding command specification
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if command is null

      • killProcessOnUnix

        public static void killProcessOnUnix(String[] commandSpecification,
                                     String pid)
                              throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                     IOException,
                                     UnexpectedProcessExitValueException
        Kills the process with the given PID by launching an external command.

        This method is only available on Unix platforms.

        The external command that is launched is obtained by replacing every occurrence of %p in the given command by the given PID.

        The given command is expected to succeed (i.e. terminate with an exit value of 0), and not to generate any error output.

        If a null command is passed, the following is used by default: sh -c kill -9 %p
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        pid - the PID of the process to kill
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's error output is not empty
        UnexpectedProcessExitValueException - if the command's exit value is not 0
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalArgumentException - if commandSpecification does not contain at least one occurrence of the %p placeholder
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows
        NullPointerException - if pid is null

      • killProcessOnWindows

        public static void killProcessOnWindows(String[] commandSpecification,
                                        String pid)
                                 throws UnexpectedProcessOutputException,
                                        IOException,
                                        UnexpectedProcessExitValueException
        Kills the process with the given PID by launching an external command.

        This method is only available on Windows platforms.

        The external command that is launched is obtained by relacing every occurrence of %p in the given command by the given PID.

        The given command is expected to succeed (i.e. terminate with an exit value of 0), and not to generate any error output.

        If a null command is passed, the following is used by default: cmd /c taskkill /F /PID %p
        Parameters:
        commandSpecification - the command to run. A null value will cause the default command to be run instead.
        pid - the PID of the process to kill
        Throws:
        UnexpectedProcessOutputException - if the command's error output is not empty
        UnexpectedProcessExitValueException - if the command's exit value is not 0
        IOException - if an unexpected I/O error occurs when spawning an external process to execute the command
        IllegalArgumentException - if commandSpecification does not contain at least one occurrence of the %p placeholder
        IllegalStateException - if invoked on Windows
        NullPointerException - if pid is null

      • getAvailableIPAddresses

        public static Set<String> getAvailableIPAddresses()
                                           throws SocketException
        Returns:
        the set of available IP addresses on the local host. These may be expressed as IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
        Throws:
        SocketException - if an I/O error occurs

      • callWithSystemProperty

        public static <T> T callWithSystemProperty(Callable<T> callable,
                                           String systemPropertyName,
                                           String systemPropertyValue)
                                    throws Exception
        Performs a method call with the given system property temporarily set to the given value.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the callable's return type
        Parameters:
        callable - The call to perform. Cannot be null.
        systemPropertyName - The name of the system property to set. Cannot be null.
        systemPropertyValue - The system property value to use for the call. May be null, in which case the system property is cleared before the call.
        Returns:
        The result of the call.
        Throws:
        Exception - If thrown by the call.
